utterances: Well, I think in a lot of ways the Beatles created the template for boy bands.
They were never called boy bands at the time.
That term didn't even come up until decades later.
OK.
But early on, they were basically covering songs by artists like Little Richard and Chuck Berry and so on.
The music was definitely bubblegum.
But most people don't think the Beatles as a boy band because the later work that they did, starting with albums like ""Revolver"" and ""Sgt.
Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club."" And that work really eclipsed some of the earlier work.
They write their own songs.
They were seen as kind of auteurs of their own destiny.
And so I think when you're talking about a boy band, the real key that underwrites what a boy band is that lack of control, right?
That there's someone else's manipulating the whole thing to produce a specific effect in young girls as their audience.
Right, but not all boy bands, then, have to sound the same to achieve that effect.
Exactly, I think when we talk about boy bands, there's a great diversity to the range of sounds that's associated with boy bands.
And maybe you should listen to some of that diversity.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""IF IT ISN'T LOVE"")
(Singing) And if it isn't love, why does it hurt so bad?
Make me feel so sad inside.
That's New Edition who, to a lot of people, is the err boy bands.
They come up in the early '80s, which you could call the golden era for boy bands.
And they're begun by Maurice Starr.
Then he goes on to start New Kids On The Block.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""STEP BY STEP"")
Step by step, ooh baby.
In 1991, New Kids On The Block makes more money than Madonna and Michael Jackson.
So I guess my question is how did Maurice Starr know that this was going to work?
So this Tuesday, Dr. Paskowitz crossed the border between Israel and Gaza to present a group of Palestinians with 15 new surfboards.
He has returned as far as New York from his adventures and joins us.
Thanks very much for being with us, Dr. Paskowitz.
Thank you, Mr. Simon.
I was suckered.
What can I say?
(Laughter) Exactly.
And I'm agreeing with Jim.
For the first time in my life, I'm agreeing with a guard.
So we're finding some common ground between officer and inmate here.
Yeah.
Amazes me too, really.
(LAUGHTER)
Fifty years will do that, I imagine.
Well, let's talk about the food of Alcatraz.
Oh, the best in the prison system, no matter where you go.
Yeah.
It was great.
We had the best food of any prison in the United States.
I'll testify to that.
Jim, what did you do after you left Alcatraz?
Twenty-two years at four more prisons.
Wow.
How does Alcatraz stand up to those other prisons?
I would go back there right now, if everything was equal.
Robert, I'm going to imagine that you would not like to go back to Alcatraz.
No.
But if I had to do time, I'd rather do it there.
And tell me about your last day, Robert, on Alcatraz.
You're never forewarned about that stuff.
They just said: Pack up your stuff; you're going.
And Jim, what was your last day on Alcatraz like?
I escorted the last inmate - Frank Weatherman - off the island and took him to town, put him on the airplane, and flew him to Leavenworth in Atlanta.
But as we're going out - and I know when I come back from this trip, I don't have a job.
I don't have a home anymore.
Oh.
What did you feel?
Well, of course, it was sad.
I didn't want the island to close.
I didn't want to leave.
I liked it there.
Yeah.
How many times have you been back?
Oh, probably a dozen.
Robert, have you ever been back?
Yeah.
I went back in 2005.
What was that like?
I was amazed.
They treated me like a rock star.
(LAUGHTER)
Robert, do you think after this conversation today, that you don't hate the guards so much?
No change in my head whatsoever.
I'm frozen; I'm an old elephant, when it comes to that.
(LAUGHTER)
Jim, I hope that doesn't hurt your feelings too much.
No, no, no, no. That's...
Oh, it's nothing personal.
It's just, he's a guard.
But I enjoyed talking to him.
(LAUGHTER)
